p: One plant species that may expand its range in the Northeast U.S. is common ragweed ( Ambrosia artemisiifolia L., Asteraceae), a widely distributed annual weed whose pollen is the leading cause of hay fever and a major trigger of asthma [ 8, 9]. Common ragweed has strong competitive growth on frequently disturbed soils [ 10] and responds positively to elevated CO 2, which can dramatically increase its growth, reproduction, and pollen output [ 11, 12, 13, 14]. Once established, common ragweed forms dense monospecific stands and is well adapted to a diversity of habitats. However, ragweed generally requires full or abundant sun for germination [ 15] and therefore usually does not grow under full tree canopy. Consequently, it is usually found in non-forested habitats such as roadsides, abandoned fields, and agricultural croplands.
